content.webTitle: Mount Eerie with Julie Doiron: Lost Wisdom Pt 2 review – stark and heartbroken

fields.headline: Mount Eerie with Julie Doiron: Lost Wisdom Pt 2 review – stark and heartbroken
fields.bodyText: It is the least of the unfairnesses to befall Phil Elverum that a late-career popularity surge came thanks to his candour about the death of his wife. As the Microphones, and then Mount Eerie, he had spent 20 years pushing lo-fi songwriting into profound and unwieldy places. Then, in 2016, Geneviève Castrée died from cancer. A 2017 album, A Crow Looked at Me, was uncharacteristically prosaic: the arrival of a backpack that Castrée had ordered for their infant daughter spelled out his desolation. Like Nick Cave’s Skeleton Tree, the album’s beauty attracted morbid sympathy from outside the usual quarters. A year later, Now Only found Elverum tilling grief while looking for sense. Then headlines suggested he had found some balance after secretly marrying actor Michelle Williams. The marriage lasted less than a year. “Unwanted attention from an inhumane, delirious, absurd other world that keeps trying to eat you,” is how Elverum recalls the tabloids breaking the story on Widows. But, he makes clear on these discomfitingly intimate songs, it wasn’t the tabloids that ended their relationship but his enduring grief. You suspect the famously private Williams may not want these things made public. Yet Elverum sings with remarkable equanimity about their breakup, transcending prurient intrigue so that any heartbroken person could find solace in his quiet pride at two bereaved people finding love (“as long as the one last leap into the dark is whole-hearted”, on Enduring the Waves) and his determination to keep loving, “vehemently” (Real Lost Wisdom). There are no recriminations, only an occasional, cathartic blast of static in these otherwise barely formed songs – largely comprising his conversational delivery, singer Julie Doiron, and a bluntly thumbed acoustic guitar. As with A Crow Looked at Me, you marvel at Elverum’s simultaneous faith in beauty after loss and ability to express ineffable sadness: “The world we could share, the one we lived in for a moment, still lies fertile in the dark,” he sings on Belief Pt 2. “I go there, alone there.” It’s a hard place to go with him; confrontationally stark, it may be the rare album that works better on paper.
